questions.question_text:
An administrator arrives at work and begins their morning checks on a four node, all-flash vSAN Cluster. They notice the vSAN datastore reached 99% capacity due to a single node failure.
How can the administrator provide temporary relief?

discussion.content:
I think C as this will free up the capacity used by the mirror copies of the components.
B is incorrect as you will require a min of 4 hosts for Raid 5.
Changing from Raid 1 to Raid 5 will require additional space during the rebuild process.

comments.content:
But there are 4-nodes - or?:
"...begins their morning checks on a four node, all-flash vSAN Cluster."

Yeap, there are four nodes and one of them crashed, so still we have 3 nodes and RAID5 will only be able to exist on 3 nodes with Force Provisioning ( but there is nothing about it in any of the answers)

discussion.content:
C. 
Since it did not say it was now out of compliance (RAID 5 requires a min of 4 hosts) and now there are only 3. Plus RAID 1 FTT1 only requires 3 and Rec 4 so it would still be in compliance and takes up 2X the space, thus the 99% capacity.

I would go with C, since no compliance was violated hence tells me it is Mirror FTT1 existing and loss of one host only impacted capacity and not compliance , how ever C is NOT supported by VMware but doable

I think C as this will free up the capacity used by the mirror copies of the components.

(preferred) and a server on Site B (non-preferred). The architect must minimize the amount of raw storage capacity used.
Which storage policy needs to be applied to the Active Directory server on site A?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I believe is correct as MS DCs are replicating and hence no need to replicate VMs i.e. mirror them

if you read again the question, the text say that we have two active directory domain controller replicating. So you don't need to replicate also the VM in the two sites. D is a possible answer because it will satisfy the requirments in the question.

comments.content: I think the right answer is C; because if you choose a preferred site the data do not go to the non-preferred site so the VM can not be accessible between site a and site b. (I've tested it before.)

discussion.content: Having researched this question a bit more I now think the answer is D, based on the article below, http://www.yellow-bricks.com/2020/12/14/vms-which-are-not-stretched-in-a-stretched-cluster-which-policy-to-use/

I think C is correct.
A will have mirrored copied of the data on site 1 and additional mirrored copies on Site 2. 
B is incorrect as the question states the design is a Stretched Cluster.
D is incorrect as data is still stretched across both sites but in the event of a split brain where the connection between data sites is down the preferred site will be the active site.

B for sure, 
A is ONLY correct if the host is to be removed permanently from the vSAN cluster
My understanding B is correct.. The default vSAN Maintenance option is Ensure accessibility.. Hence B should suffice the requirement..

comments.content: I agree with you, the host to be added already maintenance so not have any data and will not change the situation of the existing vsan cluster objects too... so if the cluster is available for maintenance without object moving, option B will work.

discussion.content: I tested in my lab as well and all storage objects had a "full data migration" applied to them, so the answer is A
Testing this command in my lab shows that all storage objects are moved to another Host, based on this I think A is correct.
